title: Steelers' medical cart breaks during game, forcing teammates to carry their injured QB off the field
text:
The Pittsburgh Steelers received criticism online for the way team medical officials handled an injury to quarterback Mason Rudolph during an overtime loss to the Baltimore Ravens Sunday afternoon

The Pittsburgh Steelers organization received an avalanche of online criticism Sunday night that, for once this season, had little to do with the way the team played during its overtime loss to the Baltimore Ravens.

Steelers second string quarterback Mason Rudolph appeared to be momentarily knocked unconscious while completing a pass during the middle of the game's third quarter.

The 24-year-old fell limp and motionless to the ground after taking a huge blow to the head from Ravens free safety Earl Thomas, one of the league's hardest hitters, who later clarified he did not intentionally hurt Rudolph.

The injury happened right before the Steelers' motorized medical cart - used to carry hurt players into the locker room - broke down on the field.

Rudolph's teammates were forced to carry the former Oklahoma State standout off the field as the visibly shaken and dazed athlete struggled to make his way to the team's facilities.

Rudolph appeared to be knocked unconscious by Ravens free safety Earl Thomas (#29) during his team's Sunday afternoon game in Pittsburgh

The 24-year-old fell limp and motionless to the ground after taking a huge blow to the head from Ravens free safety Earl Thomas, one of the league's hardest hitters, who later clarified he did not intentionally hurt Rudolph

Some of Rudolph's teammates feared the worst when laid on the field not moving

The remaining medical crew struggled to push their malfunctioning buggy off the field.

Later Rudolph was taken to a local hospital where he was diagnosed and treated for a concussion.

He has since been released and returned home and is reportedly feeling 'a bit better,' according to ESPN.

George Atallah, assistant executive director of external affairs for the NFL Players Association called the medical cart's breakdown and the way Rudolph's injury was handled 'embarrassing' considering how much money the NFL makes on the backs of of its players.

The injury happened right before the Steelers' motorized medical cart - used to carry hurt players into the locker room - broke down on the field

Rudolph's teammates were forced to carry the former Oklahoma State standout off the field as the visibly shaken and dazed athlete struggled to make his way to the team's facilities

'I guess $15 billion a year can’t buy you a working medical cart,” Atallah tweeted.

The NFL issued a statement on the matter, saying the cart that was brought out for Rudolph was not needed to get him off the field, that a backup cart was available if needed.

'After evaluating the player, medical staff determined a cart was not necessary in this instance,' the league said. 'Had one been needed, there was a backup cart on the other sideline which was immediately available. He received appropriate medical care per gameday protocols.'

Chris Mack, co-host of Pittsburgh's The Fan sports radio show, suggested Rudolph's treatment says a lot about how the NFL manages head trauma, even after years of work to improve its image on that front.

From the NFL, on the #Steelers cart issue that left QB Mason Rudolph being helped off the field rather than leaving in a cart: pic.twitter.com/1HVGeApoJD — Ian Rapoport (@RapSheet) October 7, 2019

'If "appropriate medical care" for someone in the condition Mason Rudolph was in is to walk them halfway around the damn stadium to get them to an ambulance, then we can no longer question the league's concern about head injuries: It really doesn't exist,' he tweeted.

Steelers head coach Mike Tomlin suggested the medical cart issue with Rudolph was out of his purview.

'Ask somebody that's in charge of that. I don't drive carts and things of that nature,' Tomlin told reporters when asked about the issue during the post-game press conference.

Rudolph must still participate in the league's concussion protocol procedures before he's allowed to practice fully again or play in his team's next scheduled matchup.

NFL rules require players who have suffered concussions to complete a series of medical tests before they're allowed to return to practice or play in their team's next matchup.

Steelers starting QB Ben Roethlisberger was placed on the team's injury reserve list in September after severely injured his right elbow in the team's second game against the Seattle Seahawks.

Rudolph's injury leaves only one quarterback - undrafted free agent Devlin Hodges - on the Steelers' roster.
description: The Pittsburgh Steelers are receiving criticism for the way medical officials handled an injury to quarterback Mason Rudolph during the team's overtime loss to the Ravens Sunday afternoon.
